At their exits were all manner of large people, eagerly awaiting the next normal sized person to arrive. Every single person coming down that slide was delivered immediately into the clutches of someone significantly bigger than them.

That’s why that amazon threw you in here. Apparently normal sized humans are in danger here. Does the resort lure people here for the survival of the fittest? No, no they don’t. The brochure assured you that if you die, you get brought back to life for a fee. Ok so calm down, if you die, that’s not the end, you’ll deal with the consequences, you have the money. All you have to do is get out of here, and knowing that death is not permanent, you can take the bigger risks for bigger rewards.

With that you set off swimming again, your path skirts the side of the pool. There are plenty of plants to cover your journey to what you hope is the way out of here.

1153231.content:
It took maybe three hours to sneak under the plants and waiting for amazons to clear your path to make it to the door. Just a little farther, you wait for traffic at the door to be a complete lull. It took about thirty minutes for an opening to present itself. So far escaping has not been too difficult. While you wait you see dozens, maybe hundreds of people your size being taken from the pool. Every single one of them was under the control of a taller person, a few seemed to be happy and cooperative with the situation, many were either simply obedient or too exhausted to oppose what was happening and a few fully resisted without and success.

You made your break for the opening. As fast as your legs were, here you felt woefully slow, everything being scaled for people at least twice as tall as you were. There was a stone path, and uncomfortably long straight stone path, lined with bamboo on either side. Nowhere to hide here, speed was your only way out, hopefully no giants were coming from the end.

Far ahead you see a gentle curve and a sign with arrows pointing in different directions, the one to the right was in the direction your intuition directed you. On it was written “Original Human Size Territory. Adhere to non predatory behavior codes upon entry.” Your legs find a new burst of speed as you are almost back to what seems to be safe territory. The sign flys past and ahead there is an archway bridging the gap between sections of another log fence.

WHAM!

Something solid hits you in the face and knocks you flat on your back. You see stars for a moment. Pain swirled in your head and chest from an unseen collision. You look around to see if someone or something was approaching and there was nothing in sight. Escape is still the priority, recompose yourself later. The stars are clearing quickly and you crawl yourself back up to your feet and your head hits something invisible again. It’s cold and solid. Past the invisible object regular human sized people are walking around to and from one of the primary resort buildings and to the hub of places to go. None of them notice you. You can’t hear them, whatever this was isolates sound too, maybe they can hear you. You beat against the invisible wall and risk a yell.

Outside the door on the other side the amazon who threw you over the fence discretely watches you pleading for attention. She knows you cannot escape without another giant’s help, and no giants let anything small escape. She grins watching your failing attempts to flee.

Inside you take a step back away from the invisible object and try to analyze just what’s in the way. It’s a door. A big glass door, blocking your exit. Ok it’s just a door, there has to be a way to open it. This isn’t a prison after all, or at least you hope. Your neck cannot arch upwards this close to the door and you take a few steps back, careful to watch out for giants. The bamboo lining the path might give you a place to hide if they don’t spot you first. The door clearly will not swing outward, the pain in your face and chest has confirmed that, it must swing inward. There must be a handle, and sure enough with enough room between you and the door it presents itself. It’s small and high, very high. If the door were properly scaled it would be head level, which is probably by design to keep people your size from escaping. Next to it on the wall was a black panel decorated with the emblem for the resort. It was a common sight around the resort, the room key card would unlock the doors that these panels were close to. Great, even if you could reach the handle and somehow get the leverage to open the door, it was locked.

Without a card you cannot open the door and are trapped. There are probably other ways to escape but that would mean heading back toward a higher concentration of giants. The woman being consumed by the jellyfish and it’s collection of other captive women provide you with plenty of reason to not head that way. Increasing panic creeps into your mind, angrily you wish you got caught wearing more than a bikini, at least you weren’t naked like literally every other normal sized human on this side of the fence. You force your composure back to your thoughts. You just graduated college, if you beat junior year and the trials that it gave you, you can solve a simple door and get back to safety. You can’t open the door, but you can wait for someone else to open it for you, simple. Just like when you were locked out of your dorm after curfew, all you will have to do is make sure to slip through while they are not looking. Which seems like a reasonable opportunity, since nobody is dragging you through the door, nobody will be looking for you.

The bamboo provides an excellent place to hide, the leaves and the stalks obscure any would be vision from above. Silently you wait, in the shade, the ground feels weirdly soft and warm, quickly your feet start sinking into the sandy mud mixture making up the soil. Quicksand? Not quicksand, just very muddy it seems. Every few minutes you have to grab a stalk and pull your feet up and out of the muck. While hiding you expected to see giant insects, forgetting you were still normal sized and everything is scaled for giants on this side of the wall. At some point the door will open and you can get out of here, maybe being a giant would be fun, if nothing else she could give the woman who threw you in here a good stern look eye to eye. Perhaps learning how to loom over people would be great practice for your business degree.

The musing in your head is interrupted by voices of people approaching. They must be from the inside, that door blocks almost all sound. Not wanting to squander this opportunity you gently pull your feet from the muck again, making sure not to shake the bamboo and announce your presence. Your position in the back of the bamboo certainly blocks your view, but it should make you invisible to any giants not looking for you. The voices continue to approach and you can’t see anything, that doesn’t matter, the beep from the door lock will let you know when you have to be ready to break cover and run for it. Your path through the bamboo is mapped for as much silence as possible. The voices must be right in front of you.

BEEP!

The door is swung open. A pair of humanoid giant legs are barely visible, on the path, both wearing sandals with small wedges. The door is swing wide and both sets of legs walk through, plenty of time to escape. Your legs fire like pistons launching you forward. Or they would have if the mud didn’t buckle under your feet and you fall flat in the dirt. You waste no time extracting yourself form the muck, your arms and legs plummet into the soupy earth but eventually find enough purchase to free yourself. There is still enough time to get through the door providing you don’t get stopped on the way out.

Above you hear the bamboo rustle sharply and a cheerful feminine bombard you from above, “Hi there!”

Caught.

Where the hell was this person? Roots give you some purchase to keep from sinking any more, worryingly your right foot plummets into a void. A near by stalk gives your hands something to latch on to ensure you don’t plummet.

Crushingly the door gently shuts, sealing your escape. Once your realization had completed setting in the voice returned, “Oh good, I need a snack.”

Exponentially the upward motion accelerates as it pulls you free and into the air. The tongue abruptly forces you out of the mouth banging past the teeth and lips. Suddenly the false sanctuary behind the bamboo is your world again. Upside down though. Unfortunately you are not falling back to the ground where you can try to get away form whatever this is, a lizardlike foot has your ankle clamped in it’s grip. Following the foot to the rest of the creature you see half of…it? There is a colossal lizard woman creature. The mostly invisible creature stared into your eyes, then rumbled out some words that you could feel pass over your face, “Explain to me exactly what you mean when you say you aren’t supposed to be here.” The massive digit playing between the bottom of your breasts made it difficult to choose your words. “I mean I was minding my own business on the other side of the wall trying to get some sun. Then this giant woman and I got into an argument and she threw me over the wall and I landed in the pool. I don’t want to be eaten or around giants so I didn’t come here!”

11532311222.content:
Bamboo?!? Bamboo wasn’t supposed to move without the aid of the wind. Never the less a tentacle of bamboo was synched around your neck and hand. Somehow it was still pulling you upward and away from the path, it’s a good thing your other hand is firmly holding on to the other stalk of…bamboo. The stalk flexes in a twirling motion and traps your only free hand firmly, or so you thought, your mind panicked and imagined this happening. Instinctively pulled away. This was a mistake. The animate stalk around your neck pulls you upward sharply, nearly strangling you in it’s effort. Pointlessly your free hand grabs back for the anchor but that time had passed. The sludge soil slowly slides down your body scratching and scraping all the time, until you are pulled free and up into the air. It takes only a second to feel your legs are not free, something, probably more bamboo, came out of the ground tightly wound around your ankles. Once free of the dirt the band around your neck pulls you further upward and back to the wall.

A few feet from the stone wall the bamboo stops and holds you in place, being pulled up and down in three directions by the plant. You want to try to tear off the band around your neck, but after what happened to your last hand, and unsure what to do with it, you keep it awkwardly away from your body while whatever was about to happen happens. Something or someone spoke to you a moment ago, maybe it is what is controlling the plant, maybe it isn’t? What will the better outcome be? Immediately it doesn’t matter, you are trying not to be strangled.

The leaves between you and the path slowly obscure the path over what feels like hours. Not that calling out for help is anything other than a last resort. Being isolated from the opportunity increases your unease, maybe the plants are sentient or under the control of something. As the anxiety about the bamboo bonds grows so does the discomfort and you accidentally try to adjust the bonds around your neck, it wastes no time binding your last hand to your neck just like the first. In a panic you kick your legs, after the third yank the bamboo pulls you taught and still. The pain is significant and it squeezes a scream up your throat, and then the wrap around your mouth and throat forces it right back down.

Then nothing happens, you hang there for what were definitely hours. The sun has set and the sky has fading orange streaks remaining in the dim clouds. You can’t talk and you can’t move. There is little to do beyond looking and maintaining your composure. Every so often you try to move and each time the bamboo will yank on that limb and relax some time later. People pass a few feet away, completely oblivious to your situation. Regular humans, human sized animal mixes, giants, human giant hybrids, all walk by without notice. The door opens and closes regularly as a flurry of sundown activities accelerate, you cannot see much between the dark and leaves. Finally you see a pair of legs that are familiar, the woman who threw you in. A clinking clanging from her bag confirms your concerns. Behind her is a trio of humans that are your size. Two guys and a girl. They are all wearing leashes and swimsuits, seemingly having a great time. If they had read the sign you read on your way here was accurate, they have foolishly walked into danger. You’d like to warn them but fear of that woman recovering you stifles the impulse. The coil around your mouth tightens, without provocation. Maybe it knows you want to call to someone? The trio leaves on it’s collective leash, and you continue to hang, caught in the bamboo.

Loud jingling snaps you awake from sleep. It’s close. You try to rub the sleep and some stray hairs from your face and your hands are crushed to your neck. Right, the last thing you remember is being caught by some kind of plant and it’s still holding you in the air. Unfortunately nothing has changed. Before falling asleep you had expected to wake up in a different situation, even if it wasn’t improved. Unfortunately it hasn’t. The malevolent plant was still holding you here, and no new information has presented itself to explain why. Briefly you are worried it will hold you here until you starve to death. Unable to call for help there isn’t a great chance someone will see you. The jingling continued drawing your attention downward. Much to your surprise there were three people roughly your size hiding in the bamboo waiting to escape out the door. They were all bound to a single leash and naked. They must be the same trio the woman who threw you in here was leading away earlier in the evening.

They hadn’t seen you just yet and you want to call for help. The plant caught you easily and didn’t show any consideration to your feeble attempts to resist it. Risking getting more people caught by the plant wasn’t something you wanted on your conscience even if you did desperately want to get out of this mess. Again the plant decided for you what was going to happen. The tension on your mouth was relaxed for a moment, immediately following the freedom of your lips and your first breath of fresh air, something painfully cracked across your butt, much like a whip. Pain and surprise burned through your backside and shot up and right out of your mouth. Five strokes seared your back side and following the final strike the bamboo clamped back down over your mouth.

The three people jumped with the sudden assault of sound and the first one to turn and find you was the woman.
